MATH CS 5.title: Group Studies
MATH CS 5.description: Student-directed discussion and study in a variety of subjects within Mathematics.

MATH CS 10.title: Mathematics Colloquium
MATH CS 10.comments: May be taken as often as once each quarter.
MATH CS 10.description: Students receiving credit will present talks in thei field on material arranged in consultation with the instructor. Credit assigned by the instructor will reflect the extent and quality of participation.

MATH CS 101A.title: Problem Solving I
MATH CS 101A.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
MATH CS 101A.description: Discussion and solution of nonroutine mathematical problems related with different problem-solving techniques. Possible topics are: Pigeonhole principle, use of invariants and symmetries in problem solving, coloring arguments, parity, recursive arguments, extreme principle, inclusion-  exclusion principle.

MATH CS 101B.title: Problem Solving II
MATH CS 101B.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
MATH CS 101B.description: Discussion and solution of nonroutine problems in different areas of mathematics like Graph Theory, Number Theory, Combinatorics, Geometry, Game Theory, Topology, Algebra, and Analysis.

MATH CS 103.title: Topics in Modern Algebra
MATH CS 103.description: Topics may include groups; modules; vector spaces; algebras; metric structures on vector spaces; representation theory; multilinear algebra; graded structures; universal properties; a survey of important algebraic structures.

MATH CS 108A.title: Advanced Linear Algebra I
MATH CS 108A.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
MATH CS 108A.description: An introduction to the theory of Linear Algebra with topics: Algebra of matrices, linear systems of equations, vector spaces, linear independence, basis and dimension, infinite-dimensional vectors spaces, linear transformations, matrix representation, isomorphisms, quotient spaces, dual spaces, and determinants.

MATH CS 108B.title: Advanced Linear Algebra II
MATH CS 108B.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
MATH CS 108B.description: Eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and diagonalization. Canonical form under similarity: Jordan canonical form and rational canonical form, inner product and norm. Gram-Schmidt process, adjoint of a linear operator, normal and self-adjoint operators, unitary and orthogonal operators, spectral theorem.

MATH CS 117.title: Introduction to Real Analysis
MATH CS 117.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
MATH CS 117.description: A rigorous introduction to the elements of analysis. Covers sequences, accumulation points, Bolzano-Weierstrass, Cauchy's criterion, the completeness property of the real number system, limits of functions, continuity, differentiability, compact sets, and the Heine-Borel theorem.

MATH CS 120AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Mathematics
MATH CS 120AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit providing letter designations are different.
MATH CS 120AAZZ.description: Lectures on a coherent body of mathematical topics which are not usually presented in standard mathematics courses.

MATH CS 121.title: Probability
MATH CS 121.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
MATH CS 121.description: This is a course on probability. It covers discrete and continuous distributions, combinatorial methods, generating functions, conditioning, the law of large numbers, the central limit theorem, stochastic processes, random walks, Brownian motion, and applications in biology, economics, engineering, and physics.

MATH CS 122A.title: Complex Variables I
MATH CS 122A.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
MATH CS 122A.description: Covers the basics of the topology of the complex plane, series of complex numbers, differentiability of functions of a complex variable, the complex exponential and logarithm functions, contour integration, power series and analytic continuation, among other related topics.

MATH CS 122B.title: Complex Variables II
MATH CS 122B.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
MATH CS 122B.description: Covers the basics of the topology of the complex plane, series of complex numbers, differentiability of functions of a complex variable, the complex exponential and logarithm functions, contour integration, power series and analytic continuation, among other related topics.

MATH CS 128.title: Introduction to the Higher Mathematics
MATH CS 128.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
MATH CS 128.description: A formal introduction to the language and culture of mathematics.  Students will learn how to rigorously think about mathematics and write mathematical proofs. Topics covered include: propositional logic, set theory, cardinality, number theory, and various number systems.

MATH CS 130A.title: Multidimensional Analysis: Differentiation
MATH CS 130A.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
MATH CS 130A.description: Elementary topology in R^n, directional derivatives, the differential, the chain rule, maxima and minima, manifolds and Lagrange multipliers, Taylor's formula, classification of critical points,  Multivariable Mean Value Theorem,  Inverse and  Implicit Mapping Theorems, Manifolds in R^n.

MATH CS 130B.title: Multidimensional Analysis: Integration
MATH CS 130B.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
MATH CS 130B.description: The theory of Riemann integrals: Jordan measure, Riemann integrals and Riemann integrability. Criteria for Riemann integrability using Riemann sums and step functions, Lebesgue criterion, Fubini's theorem and change of variables formula. Differential forms and their integrals, Stokes theorem.

MATH CS 199.title: Independent Studies
MATH CS 199.comments: May be repeated for credit. Creative Studies students may enroll in a maximum of 24 units of Independent Studies courses per year, with a maximum of 45 units counted toward graduation.
MATH CS 199.description: Serious independent study in mathematics with consenting faculty member.
